title: Samantha Armytage blasts Extinction Rebellion protesters for causing traffic chaos across Australia
text:
Samantha Armytage has blasted an Extinction Rebellion activist after brazen protesters caused chaos across the country to demand action on climate change.

The Sunrise host lambasted activist Miriam Robinson on Tuesday morning ahead of the group's second day of orchestrated global protests.

Police arrested more than 30 people after streets were blocked by protesters in Sydney's CBD on Monday, while six demonstrators were apprehended in Brisbane.

With another six days of demonstrations planned, Ms Armytage questioned the activist on how the movement would affect Australians getting through their day-to-day activities.

Samantha Armytage (left) lambasted activist Miriam Robinson (right) on Tuesday morning

'We saw protesters cause major problems across the country yesterday. How bad is it going to get today?' she asked.

Ms Robinson said their was a 'lots of actions' planned for Tuesday but took umbrage at her choice of the term 'bad'.

'I don't know if the right characterisation is to say how bad is going to be,' she said.

'There will be some disruption but it is important we do this to get a message through about the climate emergency.'

Ms Robinson apologised for the inconvenience but said the disruptive action was needed to bring attention to the climate emergency.

'It is hard to say that you would not be interviewing us in this because the level of disruption. Unfortunately, these are the measures we are driven to to get this message out,' she explained.

With another six days of demonstrations planned, Ms Armytage questioned the activist on how the movement would affect Australians getting through their day-to-day activities

Ms Armytage appeared fired-up by the remark and quickly shot back.

'It's interesting that you say that but do you think you're doing harm to your message?

'So you deliberately want to annoying people, so you appear on national television... what is your message? What are you trying to do?'

Ms Robinson said the group's their first message was to get the government to tell the truth about the seriousness of the 'climate emergency'.

'A lot of people do get annoyed by what we do but you'd be surprised by how many people are supportive of us. A lot of people say ''thank goodness someone is finally doing something about this'',' she said.

Activists from Extinction Rebellion dressed as bees participate in a die-in protest in Sydney

Extinction Rebellion protesters declared a 'Bee-Mergency' at Sydney's Hyde Park on Tuesday. Demonstrators were encouraged to dress up as bees for the 9am protest at Archibald Fountain

Dozens of police cars and armed response officers were seen staking out at Hyde Park ahead of the planned demonstration

SYDNEY

Extinction Rebellion protesters declared a 'Bee-Mergency' at Sydney's Hyde Park on Tuesday.

Demonstrators were encouraged to dress up as bees for the 9am die-in protest at Archibald Fountain.

'If the bees die, we die. But it's not too late - by staging this action, we are communicating to the world the necessity of making change now!' the event description said.

Dozens of police cars and armed response officers were seen staking out at Hyde Park ahead of the planned demonstration.

An activist from Extinction Rebellion dangles from the Story Bridge in a hammock as part of protests in Brisbane on Tuesday

An activist from Extinction Rebellion with his arm in a barrel of cement participating in a protest on George Street in Brisbane

Activists protest in Brisbane on Tuesday during 'Spring Rebellion'

BRISBANE

An activist dangled from the side of Brisbane's Story Bridge early on Tuesday morning.

Police negotiators arrived on the scene at 7.45am and attempted to talk him down.

The man is dangling in a hammock from a makeshift harness about 10 metres below the bridge, with a number of green flags bearing the activist group's logo.

Police said the man has enough food and resources to keep him suspended from the bridge 'for a couple of days'.

Extinction Rebellion activists also flocked to George St, in Brisbane's CBD, where they attempted to block the roads.

Protesters locked themselves to a cement barrel and boat trailer in a bid to stay put.

Emergency crews worked to clear the street and about a dozen activists were reportedly arrested for the disruption.

Extinction Rebellion activists pack down their tents at their base camp in Carlton Gardens, Melbourne, on Tuesday

The Melbourne activists have reportedly hatched a plan 'keep police guessing' and lock down the CBD for as long as possible on Tuesday

MELBOURNE

Protesters camped at Carlton Gardens on Monday evening before marching to the corner of Spring and Collins streets on Tuesday.

The group of activists were seen packing up their camping equipment in the morning, ahead of the second day of 'Spring Rebellion'.

They have reportedly hatched a plan 'keep police guessing' and lock down the CBD for as long as possible on Tuesday.

The group split up into teams of 10 and planned to storm the CBD in stages.

ADELAIDE

The activist group are planning to block traffic from 11.45am at the Central Market, on the side of Gouger Street.

The protest aims to raise awareness on how the climate emergency will affect food production.
description: The Sunrise host lambasted activist Miriam Robinson on Tuesday morning ahead of the group's second day of orchestrated global protests.
authors: Zoe Zaczek For Daily Mail Australia
